title: Classifying companies in France using machine learning
text:
Context

Several major changes:

Internal: Revamping of the French company registry, Sirene 4.
External: Implementation of a one-stop shop to declare the creation of a business.

Observation: Sicore is no longer a suitable tool ‚û® 30% automated coding.
Consequence: Ideal moment to propose a new methodology for automated NACE coding.

title: Classifying companies in France using machine learning
text:
Data

\(\approx\) 10 million observations from Sirene 3 covering the period 2014-2022.
Data labeled both by Sicore and manually.
An observation consists of:

A textual description of the activity
The nature of the activity ‚Äì NAT (23 categories)
The type of form ‚Äì TYP (15 categories)
The type of event ‚Äì EVT (24 categories)
The area (\(m^2\)) ‚Äì SUR (4 categories)

title: Classifying companies in France using machine learning
text:
Feature extraction

Word embedding: a method of vectorisation.
Pre-trained embeddings available in open-source.
We learn our own word embeddings.
Additionally, embeddings for:

word n-grams and character n-grams.

title: Classifying companies in France using machine learning
text:
Linear classifer

2 classification methods:

Softmax: a single multiclass classifier.
One-vs-all: multiple binary classifiers.

Optimisation: stochastic gradient descent algorithm.
Loss function: cross-entropy.

title: Classifying companies in France using machine learning
text:
fastText model

fastText: very simple and fast (C++) ‚Äúbag of n-grams‚Äù model.

title: Classifying companies in France using machine learning
text:

Concatenation of the text description with the names and values of the auxiliary variables:




Text
NAT
TYP
EVT
SUR




Cours de musique
NaN
X
01P
NaN




ü¢É

‚ÄúCours de musique NAT_NaN TYP_X EVT_01P SUR_NaN‚Äù

Imperfect method: 3-grams ‚ÄúAT_‚Äù or ‚ÄúT_0‚Äù used.

title: Classifying companies in France using machine learning
text:
A good overall performance


Figure¬†1: Accuracy for various level of the NACE nomenclature.

Nearly 80% of labels from the one-stop shop are correctly coded.
Most prediction errors are close in the nomenclature.

title: Classifying companies in France using machine learning
text:
Streamlining the manual coding process


Figure¬†2: Top-\(k\) accuracy per sample.

Knowledge of probabilities for each class.
The correct classification is among the top 5 most probable predictions in 94% of cases.

title: Classifying companies in France using machine learning
text:
Building a confidence index


Figure¬†3: Distribution of the confidence index based on prediction results.

Objective: discriminate between bad and good predictions.
Selected Confidence Index: difference between the two highest probabilities.

title: Classifying companies in France using machine learning
section: Efficiency of the manual coding process
text:
Efficiency of the manual coding process


Figure¬†4: Accuracy for various shares of manual coding.

Optimisation of manual coding process ‚û® Performance improvement.

title: Classifying companies in France using machine learning
text:
Deployment of the model

Models have been deployed in a production environment since November 2022.
Emerging new challenges include:

Organisational issues.
Real-time monitoring.
Regular re-training.

MLOps approach is required:

Join us on Wednesday, June 7th for a Hands-on Lab!

text:
√âvaluation de la performance

un jeu de test, 20% des donn√©es soit \(\approx\) 2.5 millions observations
un jeu issue du guichet unique \(\approx\) 15 000 observations

title: Codification automatique de l‚ÄôAPE dans le cadre du projet Sirene 4
text:
√âvaluation de la performance

4 m√©triques pour l‚Äôanalyse de la performance :

Le taux de pr√©cision : taux global de liasses bien pr√©dites (accuracy).
Le rappel : taux de bonnes pr√©dictions de la classe K parmi les vraies valeurs K.
La pr√©cision : taux de bonnes pr√©dictions de la classe K parmi les pr√©dictions K.
Le score F1 : Moyenne harmonique du rappel et de la pr√©cision.

Novembre 2022 : 1√®re mise en production de mani√®re progressive et restrictive

title: Codification automatique de l‚ÄôAPE dans le cadre du projet Sirene 4
section: Chronologie avant la mise en production d‚Äôun mod√®le
text:
Chronologie avant la mise en production d‚Äôun mod√®le

Exp√©rimentations par le SSP Lab et optimisation d‚Äôun mod√®le avec MLflow Tracking
Validation du mod√®le par l‚Äô√©quipe m√©tier
Le SSP Lab transmet le binaire aux d√©veloppeurs Sirene 4
Les d√©veloppeurs traduisent de Python √† Java le preprocessing √† effectuer en amont et int√®gre le mod√®le dans le module de codification

title: Codification automatique de l‚ÄôAPE dans le cadre du projet Sirene 4
section: Une fois le mod√®le en production
text:
Une fois le mod√®le en production

2 appels au module de classification :

Classification automatique du code APE
Aide √† la reprise manuelle via une IHM

Observabilit√© du mod√®le :

Logs accessibles seulement sur les machines de production ‚û® demande n√©cessaire
Pas de constitution de jeu d‚Äô√©valuation en continu

title: Codification automatique de l‚ÄôAPE dans le cadre du projet Sirene 4
text:
Retour d‚Äôexp√©rience

API Java vs.¬†exp√©rimentation Python :

Duplication de code
Risque d‚Äôerreurs accru

Probl√®mes li√©s √† l‚Äôutilisation de FastText :

maintenance
reproductibilit√©
s√©curit√©

Infrastructure de production rigide.

title: Codification automatique de l‚ÄôAPE dans le cadre du projet Sirene 4
text:
Retour d‚Äôexp√©rience

M√©connaissance des probl√®mes m√©tier c√¥t√© SSP Lab pour la maintenance.
Contr√¥le de version et transmission des mod√®les.
Confiance et compr√©hension du classifieur n√©cessaires c√¥t√© m√©tier/gestionnaires Sirene.
Logs difficilement accessibles et au format variable.
Pas d‚Äôacc√®s aux bases Sirene (r√©entra√Ænement).

title: Codification automatique de l‚ÄôAPE dans le cadre du projet Sirene 4
text:
Organisation vis√©e

Observabilit√©, maintenance du mod√®le c√¥t√© Sirene (appui technique du SSP Lab)
Cluster Kubernetes de production
S‚Äôaffranchir de FastText
Utilisation du plein potentiel de MLflow pour la gestion des mod√®les en production
D√©veloppement d‚Äôune API Python

title: MLOps at Insee: a use case for text classification
text:
Context

Sirene is the French national company registry
When a company registers, an activity code is attributed
Early 2023:

Refactoring of the Sirene information system
Companies register through a new channel
Performance drop of the legacy coding engine

title: MLOps at Insee: a use case for text classification
text:
Model

Text classification model which uses additional categorical variables
For now we use the fastText library
Originally trained on legacy data annotated partly by the coding engine and partly manually

title: MLOps at Insee: a use case for text classification
text:
Current state of affairs

Model trained on Insee‚Äôs cloud data science platform üòç
Coding engine developed in Java inside of a monolithic architecture üò´

Code duplication
Reproductibility issues
Increased risk of error
Maintenance problems
No monitoring

title: MLOps at Insee: a use case for text classification
text:
MLOps target

Microservice architecture running on a Kubernetes cluster

Experiment tracking and model store: MLflow
Model served via an API: FastAPI
Monitoring dashboard: Quarto and DuckDB
Quality control: annotations with Label Studio

title: MLOps at Insee: a use case for text classification
MLOps at Insee: a use case for text classification
text:
Model store

MLflow also used as a model store
Models are packaged with all the metadata necessary to run inference
Registered models are simply loaded with this command where version is a number or a "Production" tag for example

model = mlflow.pyfunc.load_model(
    model_uri=f"models:/{model_name}/{version}"
)

title: MLOps at Insee: a use case for text classification
text:
API serving

Text classification model served through a containerized REST API:

Simplicity for end users
Standard query format
Scalable
Modular and portable

Multiple endpoints: batch, online
Continuous deployment with Argo CD

title: MLOps at Insee: a use case for text classification
text: API serving

title: MLOps at Insee: a use case for text classification
text:
Monitoring

Monitoring the model in a production environment is necessary:

To detect distribution drifts in input data
To check that the model has a stable behavior
To decide when to retrain a model

Ideally, we would like to track model accuracy in real-time but expensive
In addition, monitoring of the API: latency, memory managment, disk usage, etc.

title: MLOps at Insee: a use case for text classification
text:
Monitoring

How we do it:

API logs its activity
Logs are fetched and formatted periodically
Metrics are computed from the formatted logs
Display on a dashboard

title: MLOps at Insee: a use case for text classification
text: Monitoring

title: MLOps at Insee: a use case for text classification
text:
Quality control

Test data is gathered and annotated periodically
Annotation is done with Label Studio
Performance metrics are computed on the test data
Performance is diplayed on the monitoring dashboard
Specific retraining is necessary when specific metrics decrease under a certain threshold (not done yet)
